Award.AwardTitle: The Chemical Effects of High Intensity Ultrasound: Sonoluminescence
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Kenneth S. Suslick of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and his research group will explore the origin, mechanisms and time dependence of sonoluminescence processes. Sonoluminescence does not come from a direct interaction of molecules with sound; instead, it arises from acoustic cavitation: the formation, growth, and implosive collapse of bubbles in a liquid. This research project will employ spectroscopic probes the the cavitation event, utilize streak camera and probe-pulse techniques to elucidate the time dependence of sonoluminescence, and develop diagnostics for shockwave control via mechanoluminescence from particles added to the liquid phase. A key focus of this work will be ionic liquid media, which have recently been found to produce greatly enhanced sonoluminescence intensities.

High intensity ultrasound is used in industrial and microelectronics processes, for welding, emulsification, dispersion and cleaning. It is also increasingly used to effect unique chemical transformations induced by the high temperatures and pressures present in bubbles as they collapse when liquids are irradiated with high intensity ultrasound. Students trained by this project will have unique and valuable experience in this important new chemical process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ultrasound can induce unique high-energy chemistry through this process of acoustic cavitation: the formation, growth, and implosive collapse of bubbles in a liquid, which can create extreme conditions in localized, short-lived hot spots.  The overall goal in this research has been to develop a fundamental understanding of the nature of acoustic cavitation and its chemical and physical effects, which include chemical reactivity (i.e., sonochemistry), light emission (i.e., sonoluminescence), and consequences from shockwaves produced in liquids and slurries (e.g., interparticle collisions and mechanoluminescence). In this grant period, sonolumine­scence has continued to be developed as a spectroscopic probe of cavitation, especially in ‘exotic’ liquids including molten salts and ionic liquids. 

No direct coupling of the acoustic field with chemical species on a molecular level can account for sonochemistry or sonoluminescence. Ultrasound spans the frequencies of roughly 15 KHz to 10 MHz, with associated acoustic wavelengths in liquids of roughly 100 to 0.1 mm:  these are not on the scale of molecular dimensions. Instead, the chemical effects of ultrasound derive from several non-linear acoustic phenomena, of which cavitation is the most important. During the past few years, we have begun to develop a detailed picture of the nature of cavitational collapse and its chemical effects primarily through spectroscopic studies of sonoluminescence, both of single isolated cavitating bubbles and from clouds of cavitating bubbles. 

The field of sonochemistry has undergone a renaissance during the past decade and has made a substantial impact on a wide range of the physical sciences beyond the chemical community. Importantly, sonochemistry also has substantial strategic research significance to our industrial economy. Ultrasound already has major industrial applications (e.g., cleaning, welding, emulsification), and the U.S. dominates the world market in production of ultrasonic equipment. Commercial generators of high?intensity ultrasound for large scale liquid processing are available off the shelf, and ultrasonic cleaning is now the standard for both general purpose industrial and microelectronics applications, due to restrictions on halocarbon solvents. Thus, the development of sonochemistry and its applications will advance a global market in which the U.S. has a significant commercial advantage. Broader impacts also include the education of the general public about sonochemistry and sonoluminescence, e.g., through popularized articles which the PI has written for essentially all the general science magazines and major encyclopedias.

 


Last Modified: 06/04/2015
Modified by: Kenneth S Suslick
